text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
My name is Broderick Turner.

I research technology,
race, and prejudice

and the intersection of
this technology, race,
and prejudice.

And the idea is that
race and racism get
embedded into market systems.

And our research tries to
understand how that happens

and what we can do to
extract racism out,

so these systems run
better and ultimately

lead to a better
world for more people.

Great secret of this research
is that it's always been timely.

It's always been
important to understand

how race and racism live
inside of these systems

and what we can
do to extract it.

I think the difference now is
that some people have started
to realize the value in that.

We can think about all the
data that happened in the past.

And when we think about the data
that's available in the past,

if we think about in
terms of Black people

or women or people of queer
identities, it's trash.

And so we look at our
lab and our research

as an opportunity to
sit in the present

and figure out what levers
we can move that change

things that happened in the
past to make the future better.

Can we understand the
system today and figure out

what levers to pull so that the
future is brighter and better
for more people?

So why should a CEO care about
race and technology and market
systems?

I start with a basic
assumption that CEOs

care about their share
price and CEOs care
about making more money.

And if we don't understand
your consumers that

have a different experience
than the people that develop

your products and your
systems, then we're
leaving money on the table.

There are companies that
are waking up to see that,

if we don't understand
the communities

that our products serve,
that we're doing a bad job.

And so I look at this work has
always been super important.

I'm just glad that folks
are finally waking up a bit

and going, oh, maybe this
is important to me as well.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
